docs.lead_paragraph: A consortium of six major Wall Street firms has agreed to offer the families of those killed or seriously injured on Sept. 11 free financial planning for life and deep discounts on fees the firms typically earn off investment portfolios, officials will announce today. Formed by the 9/11 United Services Group, an umbrella organization of charities, the consortium is the first systematic effort to guarantee the more than 3,000 victims' families easy access to quality investment advice. It also underscores widespread concerns among relief officials about the potential for families to fall prey to shady investment advisers.

headline.main: Free Financial Advice and Discounts on Fees

docs.abstract: Consortium of six major Wall St firms agrees to offer families of those killed or seriously injured on Sept 11 free financial planning for life and deep discounts on fees firms typically earn off investment portfolios; this is first systematic effort to guarantee more than 3,000 victims' families easy access to quality investment advice; it underscores widespread concerns among relief officials about potential for families to fall prey to shady investment advisers; six firms in consortium are American Express, J P Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Prudential Financial and Salomon Smith Barney; each firm will provide 30 experienced financial advisers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Being the tax and spend party is an accusation that the governing Labor Party believes has cost it elections in the past, and the two words are consequently ones its leaders have refused to utter since coming to power five years ago. Today it broke the taboo, unveiling to the House of Commons a new budget that for the first time includes increases in personal taxes and radical jumps in spending on the beleaguered National Health Service.

headline.main: In Calculated Risk, Blair Proposes Tax Rise

docs.abstract: Britain's governing Labor Party unveils new budget that for first time includes increases in personal taxes and radical jumps in spending on beleaguered National Health Service; risks being called tax and spend party, as it has been called in past, to test some basic assumptions: that its successful management of economy has rid it of that old reputation, that British public will tolerate higher rates in what is by European standards low-tax society, and that government can succeed in delivering visible improvements in social services before next election in three years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing nearly 1,200 employees at Group Health Inc. began a strike yesterday at the insurer's three offices in Manhattan and two offices upstate. Officials with Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union said the dispute centered on wages and G.H.I.'s efforts to have its workers with families begin paying a $26.45-a-month premium for health insurance. Under the old contract, which expired on Jan. 1, there were no insurance premiums. G.H.I. officials said that with health costs soaring, they needed their employees to contribute more toward their health insurance. G.H.I., a nonprofit insurer, provides health insurance and administrative services to 2.5 million individuals. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Workers Strike At Insurance Company

docs.abstract: Local 153 of Office and Professional Employees International Union strikes Group Health Inc offices in Manhattan and upstate in dispute over wages and GHI's effort to have its workers with families begin paying $26.45-a-month premium for health insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cleveland Heights became the first city in Ohio to extend health care benefits to same sex couples after testimony from residents divided over the new initiative. While some opposed the program, calling it an affront to marriage, others said it reflected the varied beliefs and lifestyles of the community. Only one City Council member voted against the proposal, which will provide health care benefits to same-sex couples who are city employees. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Benefits For Gay Couples

docs.abstract: Cleveland Heights becomes first city in Ohio to extend health care benefits to same sex couples (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In one room of the Palestinian Ministry of Education, the litter of papers, glass, paper clips and periodicals was ankle-deep. The filing cabinets had been ransacked, and some toppled. Personal computers sat on the desks, their hard drives ripped out. In another room, the Israeli soldiers had blasted open the safe. The explosion brought down the suspended ceiling there and in adjoining rooms, leaving a mess. Dr. Naim Abu Hommos, the deputy minister of education, said the safe had been used to keep all school test records since 1960. All were gone, he said, along with 40,000 shekels -- about $8,500 -- that had been kept there for petty cash.

headline.main: Palestinians Say Israeli Aim Was to Destroy Framework, From Archives to Hard Drives

docs.abstract: Widespread destruction of Palestinian government facilities as well as private cultural institutions in Ramallah by invading Israeli forces described; systematic effort by Israeli Army to strip institutions of Palestinian Authority of as much data as possible described; officials at afflicted ministries and institutions say money is missing, as well as laptop computers and related equipment and video players and other items; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In one room of the Palestinian Ministry of Education, the litter of papers, glass, paper clips and periodicals was ankle-deep. The filing cabinets had been ransacked, and some toppled. Personal computers sat on the desks, their hard drives ripped...

docs.lead_paragraph: In this town where the sun is so strong it bleaches the stop signs, most of the storefronts are shuttered. Were it not for Dr. Celedonio de la Cruz, the 15-bed North Runnels County Hospital might be closed, too. Within a week last October, the hospital lost its two doctors. One retired after 27 years. The other moved to Waco. In November, Dr. De la Cruz rode to the rescue of Winters, population 2,900 and slipping, about 250 miles southwest of Fort Worth. His home, at least until June, is a hospital room.

headline.main: Roving Doctors Paying House Calls to Towns

docs.abstract: Shortage of doctors in rural communities across country has led to fast-growing corps of temporary doctors who travel from town to town to fill in for colleagues who retire, die or need vacation; most find work in hospitals and clinics through recruitment and placement companies like CompHealth and Staff Care; chart of spending on temporary doctors nationwide; photo of Dr Celedonio de la Cruz on visit to Winters, Tex (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Sadly, reports that cancer treatment is available to uninsured women whose screening reveals breast or cervical cancer are exaggerated (''Tests Prove Fruitless, Fueling New Debate on Cancer Screening,'' April 9). In Texas, for example, only a tiny fraction of them are covered by the state.
docs.abstract: Dr Jerry Frankel letter on April 9 article notes only tiny fraction of uninsured women are covered by state for breast or cervical cancer screenings

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary M. Baker's elderly mother is thinking of having back surgery, and Ms. Baker has already decided that when the time comes, her mother will not be lying in a hospital room all alone. ''She's a retired nurse and she never complains,'' Ms. Baker said. ''I'm definitely having someone in there with her.'' This is more than just a doting daughter talking: Ms. Baker is a nurse herself, and president and chief executive of Chicken Soup Plus, a nursing agency in Sacramento. When she hires a private nurse for her mother, she will be joining what she feels is an emerging trend: hospitalized patients employing nurses of their own rather than relying on the hospital nursing staff.

headline.main: Nurse Deficit? Affluent Patients Hire Their Own

docs.abstract: Article on emerging trend, amid shortage of staff nurses at hospitals nationwide, in which affluent hospitalized patients are hiring their own nurses; some researchers caution that private nurses are likely to be unfamiliar with hospital and its routines, leaving themselves open to mishap; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT&T has announced a tentative agreement with unions representing 12 percent of its work force. The 18-month contract includes a 6 percent pay raise and a $250 bonus. The company will also increase pensions by 8 percent, cover higher health-insurance premiums for retirees, and pay interest of 5.5 percent on the cash in workers' retirement accounts. The contract, agreed to over the weekend, covers 27,900 employees.

headline.main: AT&T and Unions Agree on Contract

docs.abstract: AT&T reaches tentative agreement with unions representing 12 percent of its work force; 18-month contract includes 6 percent pay raise and $250 bonus; company will also increase pensions by 8 percent, cover higher health-insurance premiums for retirees, and pay interest of 5.5 percent on cash in workers' retirement accounts; workers are represented by Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (S)
